resources.string: Press the button below to add your reminder
Are you sure you would like to delete this reminder?
Conjunctivitis is an inflammation of the conjunctiva or mucous membranes called the mucosal layer.

People generally refer to conjunctivitis as a contagious red eye disease. In newborns alone can suffer from conjunctivitis because newborns can get gonococcal infection in the conjunctiva from their mother when passing through the birth canal.
Please consult your nearest Eye Specialist!

Presbyopia is an age -related condition in which a person cannot focus when looking at objects at close range. Presbyopia is an unavoidable process of eye aging and generally begins around the age of 40 years.

The eye lens is surrounded by muscles that are elastic, so it can change the shape of the lens to focus light. But as we age, the muscles around the lens of the eye lose their elasticity and harden. It is the condition of hardening of the lens muscles that causes presbyopia. The lens becomes rigid and cannot change shape, making the light entering the retina out of focus.

Age. Almost everyone will experience symptoms of presbyopia after the age of 40. Drugs. Some medications such as antihistamines, antidepressants, and diuretics are associated with symptoms of premature presbyopia, which is presbyopia in individuals under 40 years of age. Disease. Diabetes, multiple sclerosis, or heart and vascular disease can increase the risk of premature presbyopia.
Please consult your nearest Eye Specialist!

Episcleritis is an inflammatory reaction of the inner conjunctival tissue located on the surface of the scales. The skelera is an eyeball wall that consists of a strong connective tissue that is not clear and inelastic with a thickness of about 1 mm. The posterior scelera is penetrated by the optic nerve in a part called the lamina kribrosa sclera. On the skelra there is an insertion of 6 eye -moving muscles.
There is usually a purple -red swelling under the conjunctiva. If the swelling is pressed then it will cause pain.
Episcleritis occurs when there is inflammation of the tissue between the sclera and conjunctiva. Episcleritis starts from small blood vessels and spreads to the surface of the eye.
Please consult your nearest Eye Specialist!

Keratitis is a disorder caused by an infiltrate of inflammatory cells in the cornea that will cause the cornea to become cloudy, usually classified in the infected layers such as superficial, intertitisial and deep keratitis.

In superficial keratitis is a condition in which the cells on the surface of the cornea die. Keratitis can be caused by dry eye syndrome, blepharitis, chronic conjunctivitis, drug poisoning, ultraviolet rays, or can also be due to secondary infections. Keratitis can cause turbidity in the media of the cornea, then the sharpness of vision will decrease. The eyes will be red as a result of a deep pericorneal vascular injection or ciliary injection.

Keratitis can be caused by a viral, bacterial, fungal, or parasitic infection. However, the most common cause of keratitis is an injury to the cornea. This corneal injury can be due to the use of contact lenses, foreign object scratches on the cornea, or chemical contamination, such as in a swimming pool. The use of contact lenses is a major factor that can increase the risk of keratitis. This is caused, among other things, due to contact lenses that are not clean, use for too long, or due to contaminated lens cleaning fluid. In addition, vitamin A deficiency, dry eyes, intense sun exposure, and autoimmune diseases can also lead to keratitis.
Please consult your nearest Eye Specialist!

Scleritis or inflammation of the whites of the eyes is an inflammation that occurs in the deeper sclera due to the occurrence of scleral necrosis or scleromalacia, then there can be preforation of the sclera.

Scleritis looks like a slightly bluer lump. Sometimes about the whole cone circle. Scleritis itself is divided into two conditions. First, posterior scleritis, which is inflammation of the sclera located behind the eyeball. The second is the anterior sclera, which is scleritis of the sclera in front of the eyeball.

In general, scleritis or inflammation of the sclera is experienced by women in the age range of 40 years and above. If you have an autoimmune condition or a disease related to connective tissue, the risk of developing scleritis becomes increased.
Please consult your nearest Eye Specialist!

Uveitis is an inflammation that occurs in the uvea or middle layer of the eye. This condition is characterized by one or both eyes looking very red because of the many blood vessels in the uvea. Generally, uveitis is experienced by adults aged 20 years and older, but sometimes also experienced by children.

The uvea is the middle layer on the inside of the eye which consists of the rainbow membrane of the eye (iris), the lining of the blood vessels of the eye (choroid), and the connective tissue between the iris and the choroid (ciliary body). The uvea is located between the white part of the eye (sclera) and the back of the eye that captures light (retina).

Uveitis is often of unknown cause and is sometimes experienced by healthy people. However, most uveitis is associated with autoimmune disorders, which are conditions when the immune system attacks the body itself.
Please consult your nearest Eye Specialist!

Bintitan or in medical language called hordeolum is a condition when painful nodules that look like acne or boils grow on the edges of the eyelids. Most spots appear only in one eye. This condition also generally does not adversely affect the vision of the sufferer.
Itching usually occurs on the outer eyelids, but can sometimes also appear on the inside. Pimples that grow on the inside are more painful than those that grow on the outside.

The main cause of stinging is staphylococcal bacteria. Examples of infections caused by bacteria that can trigger pimples are infections that occur at the roots of the eyelashes, oil glands, and sweat glands. Staphylococcal bacteria usually live on human skin without causing disease. But the risk of stinging will increase when we touch the eyes with dirty hands.
Please consult your nearest Eye Specialist!
Thank you for choosing the symptoms you feel. Based on the symptoms selected, you may diagnosed with:
